Fig. 1 The effect of various supports on CO catalytic oxidation activity over Pt catalysts. Reaction conditions: (a) 0.1 % CO, 2 % O2 and N2 as balance gas; (b) 0.1 % CO, 2 % O2, 4 % H2O, N2 as balance gas; (c) 0.1 % CO, 2 % O2, 4 % H2O, 0.001 % SO2, N2 as balance gas, and GHSV: 200,000 h−1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Stability evaluation of various catalyst: (a) Pt/Al2O3, (b) Pt/TiO2, (c) Pt/SiO2 and (d) Pt/SnO2 under the reaction atmosphere at 180 °C. Reaction conditions: 0.1 % CO, 2 % O2, 4 % H2O, 10 ppm SO2 (when used) and N2 as the balance gas. GHSV: 200,000 h−1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of fresh catalysts after hydrogen reduction and deactivation of each catalyst. Pt/Al2O3 (a), Pt/TiO2 (b), Pt/SiO2 (c), and Pt/SnO2 (d). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TEM images of (a) Pt/Al2O3, (b) Pt/TiO2, (c) Pt/SiO2, and (d) Pt/SnO2, and HRTEM images of Pt/SnO2 (e) (f). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Chemisorption characterization profiles of Pt/Al2O3, Pt/TiO2, Pt/SiO2 and Pt/SnO2 catalysts. (a) H2-TPR, (b) O2-TPD, and (c) NH3-TPD. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TG curves of fresh (a) and spent (b) catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 FT-IR pattern of (a) Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3-S, (b) Pt/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2-S, (c) Pt/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2-S, and (d) Pt/SnO2 and Pt/SnO2-S. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 O 1s XPS spectra of (a) Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3-S, (b) Pt/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2-S, (c) Pt/SiO2 and Pt/SiO2-S, and (d) Pt/SnO2 and Pt/SnO2-S. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 S 2p XPS spectra of (a) Pt/Al2O3-S, (b) Pt/TiO2-S, (c) Pt/SiO2-S, and (d) Pt/SnO2-S. Insights into the CO oxidation and sulfur tolerance over supported Pt catalysts were carried out. The nominal 1 wt% Pt was loaded onto Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2, and SnO2 by the incipient wetness impregnation method. Results showed that the presence of H2O would promote the catalytic oxidation of CO, and Pt/TiO2 and Pt/SnO2 catalysts showed superior catalytic activity. In combination with a series of characterizations, it was concluded that excellent catalytic activity was dependent on higher dispersion and strong metal support interaction (SMSI) whether water is present or not. In the coexistence of H2O and SO2, the sulfation of the support will lead to the deactivation of the catalyst. Sulfur resistance can be improved over TiO2 with low sulfate decomposition temperature. While for Pt/SnO2 catalyst, its superior sulfur-tolerance was strongly associated with its special core-shell structure. It provides guidelines for the development of catalysts with excellent CO catalytic activity and sulfur tolerance. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO oxidation Pt-based catalysts SO2 poisoning Support effects Sulfur tolerance Data Availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Carbon monoxide (CO) is a colorless, odorless, asphyxiating poisonous gas that can cause human poisoning when its concentration in the air exceeds 0.1 vol% [1,2]. In the past two decades, the elimination of carbon monoxide has been an urgent problem in many fields such as industrial flue gas and automotive exhaust caused by incomplete combustion of fossil fuels [3–9]. Furthermore, low temperature CO oxidation is an efficient scheme for purifying the coke oven flue gas [10–12], and CO preferential oxidation (CO-PROX) in proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) because the PEMFC anodes are particularly sensitive to CO [13–17]. Catalytic oxidation owns high efficiency and energy savings [18]. Due to the enforcement of more stern laws for exhaust emissions from industrial and transportation sources, the oxidation catalyst with superior performance was pursued to eliminate CO and other pollutants. Numerous insights into CO catalytic oxidation have been reported on supported noble metal catalysts involving Pt [19], Pd [20], Ru [21] and Au [22] etc. It is the reason that noble metals have superior activity and water-resistance for CO oxidation [23–25]. Platinum group metal (PGM) catalysts are the main commercial catalysts for the removal of CO in mobile and industrial exhaust [26]. The strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) have been also extensively investigated in supported noble metal catalysts. The SMSI effects can remarkably enhance the catalytic oxidation activity by fabricating metal-oxide interface and modifying charge transport. It was found that catalytic activity in CO oxidation was strongly enhanced at the interfaces of Pt nanoparticles and mesoporous oxides [27]. Similar phenomena was also revealed on the reducible metal oxides supported two-dimensional Pt nanocatalysts especially for Pt/CeO2 owing to improved charge transport between metal nanoparticle and the oxide support [28]. The SMSI effect and catalytic performance was also dependent on the low bonding energy of metal atoms with the oxygen atom of supported metal oxide [29]. The studies indicated that the interfacial interaction between metal and supported metal oxides was crucial for CO oxidation over nanoscale heterogeneous catalysts, which provides the guidelines for the development of subsequent catalysts. However, under special condition such as coal burning, toxic SOx is an inevitable component of the exhaust gas [8]. Because SO2 significantly inhibits the activity of catalysts, it is essential that the catalyst can withstand their presence [25]. Due to the interaction of sulfur compounds with noble metal catalysts, previous research has shown that SO2 adsorption causes recrystallization of the Pt (111) facet to Pt (100) via surface diffusion, thus the surface free energy decreased [30,31]. Due to their electronegative character, sulfur species can lower the electronic density of Pt clusters, making Pt less effective in adsorbing other adsorbates [32]. Additionally, sulfur species will react with support and form sulfate. Thus the active sites and the pores will be clogged [8], resulting in worse catalytic activity [9]. Sulfur-tolerant behaviors of catalysts were strongly associated with whether their support can be sulfated. For non-sulfated support such as SiO2, it is very inert in the adsorption of acidic SO2 [33–35]. Because of the incapability of sulfur storage in SiO2, it favored rapid migration of SO2 onto Pt, followed by oxidation and facile desorption of SO3. Thus Pt/SiO2 owned the high reactivity of toward SO2 oxidation. Meanwhile a faster sulfation of some active components occurred. While for sulfated support such as γ-Al2O3 and TiO2, γ-Al2O3 is considered as the most commonly used catalyst support owing to its high surface area and thermal stability. However, Al2O3 support can be sulfated and generate Al2(SO4)3 in the occurrence of sulfur species, which resulted in the deactivation of catalyst [36]. Compared with Al2O3, TiO2 is known to be more resistant to sulfur poisoning because the sulfates generated on TiO2 are thermally unstable [37]. Taira et al. [8] investigated the catalytic combustion activity and sulfur resistance in the oxidation of CO over a series of Pt/TiO2 catalysts with different surface areas, crystal phases, and pore structures. It was found that catalysts with abundant larger pores showed better stability in the presence of SO2 and H2O within the range of 250–300 °C, while CO oxidation activity was independent on the specific surface area and crystal type. Surface reconstructing and doping modification were also common strategies for improving catalytic performance. Kim et al. [38] fabricated nano-ceria catalyst via surface restructuring to enhance the sulfur resistance for CO catalytic combustion. Xu et al. [39] prepared a series of modified 0.1Pt/Ti-A catalysts doped with WO3, and the addition of WO3 apparently enhanced the sulfur tolerance of the catalyst. Tin oxide (SnO2) is the most commonly utilized oxide and a functional material used to make resistive sensors [40], which are typically used to detect poisonous, flammable, and polluting gases. In heterogeneous catalysis, SnO2 is also often used as a support for noble metals. Pt/SnO2, for example, is an excellent catalyst for CO oxidation despite having a smaller surface area than Pt/γ-Al2O3 [41–43]. But the research on sulfur tolerance of the Pt/SnO2 catalyst is still rarely reported. Hence, in this work, supported Pt catalysts were prepared on different materials (γ-Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2, SnO2), and their catalytic activity and sulfur resistance were investigated for CO complete oxidation. Moreover, XRD, TEM, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, BET, FT-IR, TG, XPS and other characterizations were used to elucidate the mechanistic mechanism on different sulfur resistance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In this study, four kinds of supported Pt catalysts were prepared namely Pt/Al2O3, Pt/TiO2, Pt/SiO2 and Pt/SnO2. Firstly, boehmite was thermally decomposed at 550 °C for 2 h to obtain a γ-Al2O3 support [44]. Commercial anatase TiO2 (99.8 %; Aladdin), and as-synthesized SiO2 supports were used. SnO2 support was synthesized by the precipitation method. Raw materials used in this process were tin chloride (SnCl4·5H2O, Macklin, AR) and ammonia (NH3·H2O, analytical grade). SnCl4·5H2O was dissolved in deionized water and stirred for 30 min to form a clear solution. With constant vigorous stirring, the ammonia solution was gradually dropped into aqueous solutions of SnCl4 until the pH reached 9. After filtering and washing with isopropanol several times, the obtained white precipitates were dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 9 h, and then calcined at 600 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. Supported catalysts with nominal Pt loading of 1 wt% were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. The supports were first pressed to a wafer and then crushed into 40–60 mesh particles, the particles were then impregnated by H2PtCl6 (Shen Yang Kuang Ye, AR) solution quantified by ICP-OES in advance. Then four kinds of supported Pt catalysts were obtained by drying for 12 h in the oven at 120 °C, followed by calcining for 2 h in the muffle oven at 500 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. A fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor was used to reduce all synthesized catalysts by 10 vol% H2/Ar (Airgas, 99.999 %) for 2 h at 450 °C. 2.2 Catalytic evaluation CO oxidation activities for as-prepared catalyst were performed in a continuous flow fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor. An amount of 0.5 mL catalyst was loaded into the reactor under the following conditions: 0.1 vol% CO, 2 vol% O2, 4 vol% H2O (when used), 10 ppm SO2 (when used) and N2 as the balance gas. Furthermore, deionized water was used to humidify the reactive gases through a saturator, and the steam concentration was controlled by adjusting the saturator temperature (30 °C for 4 vol%). In addition, the inlet pipeline was maintained at 120 °C to avoid the condensation of H2O. During catalytic evaluation, the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was set at 200,000 h−1, and the concentration of CO was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890B) equipped with a Flame Ionization Detector (FID). The conversion of CO was calculated using the following equation: (1) X c = [ C c ] in − [ C c ] out [ C c ] in × 100 % where X c means the conversion of CO, [ C c ] in and [ C c ] out are inlet and outlet concentration of CO. The size of Pt nanoparticles could be estimated by CO chemisorption as follows [45]: (2) d = 6000 M Pt ρ φ A Pt N A where M Pt denotes as the molar weight of Pt (195.08 g mol−1), ρ is the density of Pt (21.45 g cm−3), φ is the dispersion of Pt, A Pt represents the surface area of Pt atom (8.06 × 10−20 m2 per atom), and N A is the Avogadro constant (6.02 × 1023 mol−1). 2.3 Characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a PANalytical Empyrean diffractometer using a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) from 10° to 80° with a scanning speed of 8 °/min. A Quantachrome NOVA 2200e instrument was used to determine the specific surface areas (SBET) of the catalysts using the BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) method based on N2 adsorption isotherms obtained at − 196 °C. The samples were degassed at 150 °C under vacuum for 3 h prior to the measurement, and the pore size distributions were measured using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method based on the isotherm data. The total pore volume was determined by N2 adsorption at p/p0 = 0.98. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded on a JEM-2100 at 200 kV after the sample was dispersed in ethanol and then dropped on copper grids covered with carbon film. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) was collected on ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fischer) spectrometer at an ultrahigh vacuum (8 × 10−10 Pa) with Al Kα (1486.68 eV) radiation as the excitation source. The Avantage software was used for the analysis, and all binding energies (BE) were referenced to C 1s at 284.8 eV. All the temperature programmed tests were measured by Quantachrome CHEMBET pulsar adsorption instrument. The hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were used to evaluate the reducibility of the catalysts, 150 mg catalyst was pretreated for 1 h at 300 °C in an Ar environment and cooled to 25 °C. The basis line sustained stable by shifting a combination of 10 % H2/Ar. After then, the sample was heated to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The hydrogen consumption was detected by the TCD detector. In order to perform temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen (O2-TPD), the samples with a mass of 300 mg were reduced in a 10 % H2/Ar mixture at 450 °C for 2 h and then pretreated for 30 min at 500 °C with a 3 vol% O2/He mixture. The samples were then cooled to 25 °C and maintained for 1 h. He gas was then shifted and stabilized for 30 min. O2-TPD signals were collected at a rate of 10 °C/min from ambient temperature to 900 °C. The ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were used to determine the acidity of the catalysts, the samples with a mass of 100 mg were reduced in a 10 % H2/Ar mixture at 450 °C for 2 h. The sample was then cooled to 30 °C. After that, the sample was kept in a 10 % NH3/N2 atmosphere for 60 min. He was then fed to for 60 min eliminate the extra NH3. Then the samples were heated from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min to obtain NH3-TPD signals. The Pt dispersion, which is determined by CO chemisorption, is calculated as the ratio of surface Pt atoms to nominal Pt atoms. When estimating the dispersion, one CO molecule is considered to be adsorbed on one Pt atom. Pt dispersion over catalysts was evaluated using CO chemisorption on the chemisorption apparatus above. For all catalysts, more specifically, 50 mg catalyst was pretreated at 450 °C with 10 vol% H2/Ar for 2 h and cooled to 30 °C after purging with Ar for 30 min. Finally, after switching the carrier gas to He for 30 min and stabilizing the TCD baseline, CO gas was pulsed into the system until the adsorption was saturated. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed from 38 °C to 1000 °C using a Netzsch STA 449 F3 analyzer with an air flow rate of 40 mL·min−1 at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were collected in solid state using a Nicolet 6700 FT-IR instrument outfitted with a KBr beam splitter and an MTC nitrogen-cooled detector. Before the experiments, the samples and KBr powder were heated for 4 h under an infrared lamp. The spectral data were acquired in a frequency region of 4000–500 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance for CO combustion Fig. 1(a) and (b) depicted the catalytic activity for CO combustion in dry and wet conditions over all four catalysts as a function of temperature. It can be seen that the catalyst performance of Pt supported on different supports was different. In contrast, four catalysts with identical Pt content demonstrated different CO oxidation activities, which could be attributed to the synergistic effect of Pt and supports. It is worth noting that, whether under dry or wet conditions, the activity of each catalyst follows the following rules: Pt/TiO2 ≈ Pt/SnO2 > Pt/Al2O3 ＞ Pt/SiO2. Under the simulated industrial conditions (0.1 %CO + 2 %O2 + 4 %H2O + 0.001 %SO2), the light-off performance for these catalysts were tested and shown in Fig. 1(c). In the presence of SO2, the inhibition of activity for different catalysts varied, while Pt/SnO2 maintained the best performance among them. As listed in Table 1, whether under dry or wet conditions, the T50 and T90 values of Pt/TiO2 and Pt/SnO2 were much lower than those of Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/SiO2. For the catalytic reaction, the smaller the specific surface area of the catalyst, the less the reactant can contact the active site of the catalyst, which is detrimental to the catalytic reaction. The BET surface areas of Pt/Al2O3, Pt/TiO2, Pt/SiO2 and Pt/SnO2 were 179.0 m2 g−1, 102.4 m2 g−1, 289.0 m2 g−1 and 13.3 m2 g−1, respectively. Though Pt/SiO2 catalyst owned the highest surface area, its CO catalytic activity was poor. Pt/SnO2, on the other hand, has the smallest specific surface area but relatively good catalytic activity, which is similar to the findings of Yamaguchi et al. [41]. It is possible to conclude that the catalytic activity was independent on its physical parameters, such as surface area and pore volume. Additionally, it should be noted that under wet conditions, all four catalysts had higher catalytic combustion activity for CO relative to dry conditions. Results were shown in Fig. S1. This is possibly the reason that the presence of water altered the reaction pathway of CO catalytic oxidation, which was consistent with the water-promoting reaction mechanism for CO catalytic oxidation [25]. Catalytic performance in dry CO + O2 + SO2 mixture was further studied and shown in Fig. S2. By comparison, the inhibition of SO2 to catalytic activity was obvious for all the catalysts. The dispersion of Pt on the catalyst was approximately calculated by CO chemisorption. As can be seen, the catalytic activity of the four catalysts was dependent on the dispersion of Pt. As for the Pt/SnO2 catalyst, there was no significant CO adsorption to determine its dispersion. This result is consistent with that of Okanishi's study, which showed that only a small amount of CO adsorption occurred even though a high loading of Pt (40 and 50 wt%) is supported [46]. It is speculated that the strong metal-support interaction between Pt and SnO2 existed in the reducing atmosphere, resulting in a significant change in CO adsorption and the chemical state of Pt over reduced tin oxide. Peng et al. proposed that different Pt sizes may result in diverse Pt dispersion, chemical states, and coordination numbers, all of which have a significant impact on the catalytic activity [45]. To compare, Pt dispersion was also calculated based on the average particle size of subsequent TEM data. 3.2 Stability evaluation It is essential to possess superior catalytic stability for industrial catalyst. Therefore, their catalytic stability and sulfur tolerance in CO oxidation were evaluated at 180 °C in a humid atmosphere to simulate the industrial application. As illustrated in Fig. 2, the CO conversion over Pt/Al2O3, Pt/TiO2, Pt/SiO2, and Pt/SnO2 reached 100% in the humid atmosphere (CO + O2 + H2O) at 180 °C during the initial 10 h. However, there were different trends on SO2 resistance. Fig. 2(a) showed that for the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, when SO2 was introduced into the reaction atmosphere, CO conversion gradually decreased within 10 h. Eventually, its CO conversion decreased to around 30 %. In contrast to the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, Fig. 2(b) showed that there was a slight effect on CO conversion for Pt/TiO2 within the initial 2 h after SO2 was added. After that, it gradually deactivated, and 10 h later, its catalytic activity on CO had dropped to around 36 %. Fig. 2(c) revealed that there was a remarkable drop in the catalytic oxidation activity of CO over Pt/SiO2 catalyst after the addition of SO2, and its CO conversion was around 21 % within 10 h. As for the SO2 tolerance of the Pt/SnO2 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 2(d), it had the slowest deactivation rate compared to the other catalysts. There was no alteration in activity after the first hour of SO2 addition, and CO conversion was maintained at about 53 % after 10 h continuous introduction of SO2. In conclusion, due to the deactivation led by the continual addition of SO2, only Pt/SnO2 among four catalysts retained relatively high catalytic activity after 10 h. It is worth mentioning that after SO2 was removed from the reaction environment, the catalytic activity of CO recovered to 100 % in all of the samples. Furthermore, among the four catalysts, the activity of Pt/SnO2 was rapidly recovered. As a result, it is plausible to conclude that the Pt/SnO2 catalyst has better sulfur tolerance. After stability testing, the spent catalysts were collected for further analysis, and the collected samples were labeled as Pt/Al2O3-S, Pt/TiO2-S, Pt/SiO2-S, and Pt/SnO2-S, respectively. According to the analysis, it was seen that there was a relative slow deactivation rate on the catalysts namely Pt/Al2O3, Pt/TiO2 and Pt/SnO2, whose support can be sulfated. And their activities reached higher plateau than that of Pt/SiO2. For the non-sulfated support SiO2, SO2 directly attacked Pt active sites. Thus a rapid deactivation was illustrated. According to S2p XPS result of Pt/SiO2-S, there was no residual sulfur species. It was assumed that the deactivation was attributed to the competitive adsorption of SO2 on Pt active sites. While for the sulfated support such as Al2O3, TiO2 and SnO2, there were different sulfur-tolerant behavior for their supported Pt catalysts. For Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, CO conversion began to decrease as soon as SO2 was introduced. Although sulfur-tolerance can be enhanced by transferring the formed surface sulfate to bulk phase one, the improvement was limited owing to the higher decomposition temperature of aluminum sulfate. Thus the activity gradually decayed. From TG results, it was confirmed that there was the maximum sulfur deposition on Pt/Al2O3-S. But the inconsistency on residual sulfur between TG and S2p XPS, it was further validated that partial sulfur was transferred from surface to the bulk. For Pt/TiO2, TiO2 can also be sulfated and formed TiOSO4. Whereas TiOSO4 possessed lower decomposition temperature, especially for its surface sulfate. CO conversion reached the minima (36 %) when the formation and decomposition of sulfates achieved equilibrium. While for Pt/SnO2, its excellent sulfur resistance was attributed to the protective amorphous SnOx layers formed during the pretreatment of reduction-oxidation process. In essence, high content of Sn0 and lower decomposition temperature of tin sulfates was conductive to enhance the sulfur-tolerance. Similarly, there was an equilibrium between the formation and decomposition for sulfates, at which CO conversion reached the plateau. But the value was higher compared with other catalysts. The pulse SO2-resistant performance of Pt/SnO2 catalyst was tested. As was shown in Fig. S6, the influence of SO2 was almost reverse for CO oxidation under free-SO2 condition. Compared with the first pulse, there was a faster response for deactivation when SO2 was switched on twice. It indicated that partial activity cannot be completed regenerated. 3.3 Structural characterization of catalysts Fig. 3 showed the XRD patterns of four H2-reduced fresh and spent catalysts. γ-Al2O3, anatase TiO2, and SnO2 can be found in Pt/Al2O3, Pt/TiO2 and Pt/SnO2, respectively. The broad diffraction peak at around 2θ = 22° for Pt/SiO2 corresponded to amorphous SiO2 [47]. It can be seen that there was no obvious Pt diffraction peak for the Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/SnO2 catalysts, suggesting that Pt was well dispersed on the support, while there was a slightly noticeable Pt diffraction peak on the catalyst Pt/TiO2, indicating that some Pt particles were agglomerated. And Pt particles on the Pt/SiO2 catalyst were more obviously gathered, indicating the formation of larger Pt particles on the catalyst Pt/SiO2, which was also observed in the subsequent TEM images. Thus the worst CO oxidation activity for Pt/SiO2 catalyst was possibly sourced from its larger Pt particles. It is worth mentioning that, as shown in Fig. 3(d), obvious metallic Sn was created on Pt/SnO2 catalyst after hydrogen reduction, and a metallic tin diffraction peak was also found in the Pt/SnO2 catalyst after deactivation, but its strength was relatively weak after the stability test. It was reported that there was the strong metal support interaction (SMSI) between Pt and SnO2 in a reducing environment. As a result, intermetallic compounds were generated between Pt and tin [46]. Therefore, it was assumed that the sulfur-tolerant ability over Pt/SnO2 may be due to the metal-support interaction and the formation of metallic tin in the reducing atmosphere. Subsequently, it was also observed some changes in the microstructure as a result of the interaction by using TEM observation. Fig. 4 showed the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of the four catalysts and high-resolution TEM micrographs of the Pt/SnO2 catalysts. As was shown in the images, it can be seen that Pt nanoparticles were well dispersed on the Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2, and SnO2 surfaces with a small mean size of 1.3 nm, 1.2 nm, 20.8 nm, and 1.8 nm, respectively. It was worth noting that the TEM image of the Pt/SiO2 catalyst showed the presence of relatively large Pt particles. This phenomenon was consistent with the previous XRD data, which showed that there were obvious Pt characteristic peaks on the SiO2 support. According to the relationship between Pt particles and dispersion, the smaller the Pt particles, the higher the dispersion of precious metals on the catalyst [45]. According to the relationship above, Pt dispersion may be estimated by particle size, therefore the dispersion of Pt in Pt/Al2O3, Pt/TiO2, Pt/SiO2, and Pt/SnO2 catalysts was 83.92 %, 96.12 %, 5.41 %, and 60.14 %, respectively. For Pt/Al2O3, Pt/TiO2 and Pt/SiO2 catalysts, the order of the estimated Pt dispersion measured by TEM images was in good accordance with the one of the Pt dispersion measured by CO adsorption. To avoid the aggregation of Pt species, fresh Pt/SiO2 was reduced with mild hydrazine hydrate (N2H4). The detailed synthetic process was described in Supplementary data. Pt particles with a smaller size distribution of 3–5 nm was successfully synthesized (TEM observations in Fig. S4). The N2H4-reduced catalyst noted as Pt/SiO2-N2H4 was also evaluated for CO oxidation under free-water as well as wet conditions. Fig. S5 revealed that the catalytic activity of Pt/SiO2-N2H4 and Pt/SiO2-H2 was similar, despite Pt particle size on them were quite different. It implied that the particle size effect for CO oxidation was not significant for Pt/SiO2. Due to the interaction between noble metals and support during the hydrogen reduction of Pt/SnO2 catalyst, Pt particles of Pt/SnO2 got relatively large. As shown in Fig. 4(e) and (f), the unique particles with the core-shell structure were fabricated. It was proposed that the core-shell structure was generated by the phase separation of tin species such as PtSn or Pt3Sn from particles with intermetallic compounds in a mild oxidative atmosphere, and that the core and shell portions were made up of the intermetallic compounds and the amorphous SnOx, respectively [48]. The shell of SnO2 hindered the diffusion and adsorption of CO on Pt species. The structure may be related to its better sulfur tolerance. In addition, it was assumed that there was different CO oxidation mechanism on Pt/SnO2. Following that, additional characterization was performed to investigate its sulfur resistance. 3.4 Chemical states and redox property H2-TPR analysis was performed to reveal the differences in catalytic activity, and the results were displayed in Fig. 5. As seen in the figure, the peaks on the TPR curve for Pt/Al2O3 at about 286 °C were ascribed to the reduction of Pt species on the catalyst. The TPR curves of Pt/TiO2 had many reduction peaks, which corresponded to the reduction of different species, respectively. The peak near 167 °C, for example, was responsible for the reduction of platinum species on the catalyst, the peak at 367 °C was attributable to the reduction of capping oxygen on TiO2 surface, and the peaks at 473 °C and 558 °C were due to the reduction of TiO2 support [49]. For the TPR curve of Pt/SiO2, the broad peak at 481 °C was attributed to the reduction of Pt species [50]. This result indicated that isolated metallic Pt species was formed at a higher temperature. As for the TPR curve of Pt/SnO2, the peak at 172 °C was attributed to the reduction of accessible PtOx weakly interacted with the support, the peak at 284 °C was attributed to the reduction of PtOx strongly interacted with the support and also possibly some partial reduction of SnO2, most likely at the interface with the Pt nanoparticles, and finally, it was found that bulk SnO2 was reduced at temperatures above 450 °C [51]. For the TPR curves of four catalysts, the low reduction temperature of Pt species indicated that it had excellent redox performance. In the figure, the reduction temperature of Pt species followed the order of Pt/TiO2 < Pt/SnO2 < Pt/Al2O3 < Pt/SiO2, which also indicated the difference in redox performance of catalysts. And it was seen that the difference in redox performance was consistent with the difference in CO catalytic oxidation activity of each catalyst mentioned above. O2-TPD profiles of four samples were shown in Fig. 5(b). The peak below 350 °C in the O2-TPD curve was the desorption peak of adsorbed oxygen on the surface, the peak between 350 °C and 500 °C was the desorption peak of oxygen at the oxygen vacancy, and the peak above 500 °C was the desorption peak of lattice oxygen on each catalyst support [44]. The curve of Pt/TiO2 demonstrated that the catalyst had formed more oxygen vacancies, which had a certain correlation with its better activity. NH3-TPD curves for four samples were depicted in Fig. 5(c). The peaks centered at 150–250 °C, 250–350 °C and 350–450 °C were assigned as the weak acid site, the medium-strong acid sites, and the strong acid site, respectively. The surface acidity of each catalyst may play different roles on the adsorption of SO2. It was observed that Pt/Al2O3, Pt/TiO2, and Pt/SiO2 catalysts had weak acid sites with a certain amount, while Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/TiO2 catalysts had medium-strong acid sites, and Pt/Al2O3, Pt/TiO2, and Pt/SnO2 catalysts had a few strong acidic sites. However, there were other factors affecting the sulfur resistance of the catalysts, such as whether the support can be sulfated or not, which will be discussed in the subsequent characterization. 3.5 FT-IR and TG results Fig. 6(a) and Fig. 6(b) showed the TG profiles of the fresh and spent catalysts, respectively. It can be seen that the weight loss of the fresh catalyst occurred when the temperature was below 200 °C, which was related to the desorption of water. Fig. 6(b) indicated that sulfur deposition occurred in different degrees over the spent catalysts. When the TG curves of Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3-S were compared, the spent catalyst showed higher weight loss, with a total weight loss of 11.52 %. This was due to the fact that the typical catalyst with alumina as the support reacts more easily with SO2 to create aluminum sulfate species [52]. For the spent Pt/TiO2-S, water desorbed at below 200 °C, and the deposited sulfate species degraded at around 470 °C. Its total weight loss was 3.8 %. It was worth noting that there was no difference in the total weight loss for Pt/SiO2 before and after deactivation, which could be due to the fact that the support SiO2 is inert and it is difficult to react with SO2 to form sulfate. According to the TG curves of the spent Pt/SnO2-S, its mass began to increase at about 400 °C. As previously stated, metal Sn species were generated after the reduction of the catalyst, and the XRD pattern of the deactivated catalyst demonstrated that some metal Sn species remained. As a result, it was possible that the metal Sn in the catalyst was re-oxidized during TG test under air atmosphere, resulting in the increase in weight. To further demonstrate whether sulfate species were formed on the deactivated catalyst, FTIR was performed on the fresh and spent catalysts. The infrared diagrams of fresh and sulfur-poisoned catalysts were presented in Fig. 7. For all catalysts, the peaks at around 3440 cm−1 and 1630 cm−1 were assigned to O-H stretching vibrations in water [53]. The infrared spectra of the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst before and after deactivation, as shown in Fig. 7(a), showed that, except for the peaks assigned to O-H vibration in water at 3444 cm−1 and 1633 cm−1, the peak near 1153 cm−1 was associated with the characteristic absorption peak of SO4 2-, indicating the presence of sulfate species, whereas the peak near 759 cm−1 may be attributed to the characteristic absorption peaks of Al2O3 [54]. A similar phenomenon occurred for the Pt/TiO2 catalyst in Fig. 7(b), which also showed a characteristic absorption peak of sulfate at 1153 cm−1, indicating the formation of sulfate, which was also proved by TG results. The wide absorption band at about 759 cm−1 were mostly assigned to Ti-O and O-Ti-O vibrations [55]. For the fresh and spent Pt/SiO2 catalysts in Fig. 7(c), it was found that the peaks at 3440 cm−1 and 1631 cm−1 in both fresh and deactivated Pt/SiO2 catalysts were assigned to O-H stretching vibrations in water molecule, and the peak close to 1103 cm−1 was assigned to an antisymmetric stretching vibration of siloxane bonds, while the peak close to 808 cm−1 was assigned to the symmetric stretching vibration of SiOSi bonds [56]. At the same time, unlike Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/TiO2, there was no typical peak of sulfate on Pt/SiO2 catalyst, indicating that no sulfate species were generated on Pt/SiO2 catalyst, which also corresponded to TG data. As shown in Fig. 7(d), the peaks at 3438 cm−1 and 1627 cm−1 were attributed to O-H stretching vibration, while the peaks near 700 cm−1 may be attributed to vibrations of stretching of the O-Sn and vibrations of flexion of the O-Sn-O [57]. No obvious characteristic absorption peak of sulfate was observed on the deactivated catalyst Pt/SnO2-S. 3.6 XPS results XPS was used to characterize the samples in order to investigate the shifts in species and chemical states over the catalyst following the reaction of H2O coexisting with SO2. The O 1s XPS spectra of samples were shown in Fig. 8, which could be divided into two separate peaks. Peaks at lower binding energies of 529.7–539.8 eV were attributed to lattice oxygen (denoted as Oβ) on the catalyst surface, while peaks at higher binding energies of 531.3–534.3 eV were assigned to the surface adsorbed oxygen (denoted as Oα), such as *O2 2− and *O− [25,58,59]. Table 2 showed the binding energy values of each peak, as well as the ratio of Oα/(Oα + Oβ) calculated based on the associated peak area. It can be found from the table that the content of surface adsorbed oxygen (Oα) on the surface of the catalyst changed to some extent before and after deactivation. Since the deactivated catalyst was evaluated under conditions containing H2O and SO2, the surface adsorbed oxygen of the deactivated catalyst would change accordingly. The presence of H2O in the reaction atmosphere led to an obvious increase in hydroxyl groups on the surface of some catalysts such as Pt/TiO2-S and Pt/SnO2-S. In view of O1s core level, the assignment of positive shifts to Os was further validated that more OH groups were formed on the surfaces [60]. However, the presence of hydroxyl groups on the surface of the Pt/SiO2 catalyst was not obvious for a SiO2 support with hydrophobic properties. The decrease in hydroxyl groups on the surface of the deactivated Pt/Al2O3 catalyst may be caused by SO2 poisoning, which inhibited the content of hydroxyl groups on the surface. Comparatively, Pt/SnO2 catalyst presented relatively higher Oα/(Oα + Oβ) value, suggesting more chemisorbed oxygen species on Pt/SnO2. In addition, as shown in Fig. 9, XPS characterization of sulfur elements on the catalyst surface was performed on samples treated with H2O and SO2. According to Fig. 9, the peaks with binding energies of around 168.7 eV and 169.9 eV were assigned to the sulfate species S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2, respectively [61]. It was worth noting that only the Pt/SiO2 catalyst had no obvious spectral peak in the S2p XPS spectra of all samples, indicating that the related sulfur species did not form on the surface of this catalyst. This result was also corresponding to the TG curve and FTIR pattern. The atomic content of surface S atoms of each catalyst was listed in Table S1. Furthermore, BET measurements (Table 1) revealed that the average pore diameter of the Pt/TiO2 catalyst was around 12 nm. It has been found that sulfuric acid did not easily accumulate in the pores of Pt/TiO2 samples with an average pore width of higher than 10 nm [8]. As a result, the sulfate species identified by XPS should be primarily attributable to TiOSO4 species [9], and the formation of this species led to the reduction of the CO oxidation activity of the catalyst. This may also lead to the generation of more surface sulfur species, and it can be seen from the Table 3 that the Pt/TiO2 catalyst had the highest amount of S atoms on the surface. Fig. S3 showed the Pt 4f XPS spectra of fresh and spent samples, and the corresponding peaks appeared at 70–78 eV, which was in accordance with previous literature [9]. Because the binding energies of the most intense photoemission lines of Pt emerging from Pt 4f levels were overshadowed by the existence of an Al 2p peak, the Pt 4d5/2 spectra indicated the peak binding energies of distinct Pt species found at Pt0 (314.02–314.07 eV) and Pt4+ (318.10 eV) shown in Fig. 2(S) [62]. Table S2. listed the chemical state of Pt species obtained from XPS results. The ratio of metallic Pt in Pt/SiO2 was the highest (93 %) among all catalysts. Since there was a weak interaction between Pt species and SiO2, Pt aggregation was inevitable during reduction in H2 atmosphere. Thus there was higher metallic Pt content over the reduced Pt/SiO2 owing to poor electron transport. Pt/TiO2 and Pt/SnO2 had similar metallic Pt contents (60.7 % for Pt/TiO2, 65.8 % for Pt/SnO2) in fresh catalysts. After the reaction proceeded in SO2 atmosphere, there was a remarkable decline from 60.7 % to 46 % on Pt0 ratio on the spent Pt/TiO2. Meanwhile there was a slight decrease on Pt0 for Pt/SiO2. During the reaction, it indicated that oxygen probably activated at Pt0 sites, during which partial Pt0 was oxidized. As compared, the chemical state of Pt in Pt/SnO2 remained almost invariant after reaction. It suggested that Pt0 owned superior stability or it was not the active site for oxygen activation for Pt/SnO2. According to CO chemisorption experiment, there was undetectable CO adsorption on the Pt surface. It was assumed Pt site was not accessible to CO. In combination with TEM results, it was further validated that Pt nanoparticles were confined within the SnO2 shell. In view of the analysis above, it was speculated that different reaction mechanisms were followed on Pt/SnO2 and other catalysts namely Pt/TiO2, Pt/SiO2 and Pt/Al2O3 owing to various active sites. For the front one, oxygen vacancy was the active site, while CO oxidation was dependent on the synergy effects of Pt0 and oxygen vacancy on the latter. ER mechanism for CO oxidation was proposed, in which CO was directly oxidized to CO2 by chemisorbed oxygen on the catalyst. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations also discovered that the interaction between CO and oxidized cobalt oxide clusters was exothermic, indicating that chemisorbed oxygen on cobalt oxide clusters can successfully oxidize CO to CO2 at low-temperatures [63]. Additionally, it was revealed that ER mechanism for CO oxidation on Sn doped carbon nanotube (Sn-CNT) has a lower energy barrier than the LH mechanism [64]. It indicated that the Sn-CNT surface was covered by O2, and the adsorbed O2 on the surface was responsible for excellent CO oxidation performance. Considering the Pt@SnO2 core-shell structure, it was proposed that CO oxidation followed an ER mechanism that CO molecules directly oxidized to CO2 by the chemisorbed oxygen species on the amorphous SnOx shells that were attached to Pt. 4 Conclusion In the present work, Pt/Al2O3, Pt/TiO2, Pt/SiO2, and Pt/SnO2 catalysts with similar nominal Pt content were prepared via an incipient wetness impregnation method. Whereas different catalytic behaviors were illustrated for CO combustion and sulfur-resistant stability. Pt/TiO2 and Pt/SnO2 catalysts showed excellent catalytic activity of CO oxidation, and Pt/SnO2 among the four catalysts showed the slowest deactivation rate and highest catalytic stability. Based on various characterizations, the effects of redox capacity, surface acidity and surface hydroxyl group on sulfur tolerance were elucidated, it was found that the catalytic activity of catalysts was closely related to the dispersion of Pt and the redox properties of catalyst as well as SMSI between Pt and support. The activity of CO oxidation followed the following order of Pt/TiO2 ≈ Pt/SnO2 > Pt/Al2O3 > Pt/SiO2, which was in good accordance with Pt dispersion. Meanwhile their sulfur-tolerant stabilities also followed the order above. It was possibly closely related to whether the support was sulfated or not. The introduction of SO2 would occupy the active site Pt on non-sulfated support such as SiO2. Thus there was a faster decline on the catalytic activity of Pt/SiO2 with the addition of SO2. While the sulfur tolerance was enhanced when Pt was loaded over Al2O3 with higher sulfur capacity and TiO2 with low sulfate decomposition temperature. Different case was illustrated on Pt/SnO2. Due to the strong metal-support interaction after reduction pretreatment of Pt/SnO2 catalyst, Pt particles were coated with a layer of weakly oxidized Sn species, and the sulfate species generated on Pt/SnO2 catalyst was also relatively minimal. Therefore, superior sulfur resistance was achieved. CRediT authorship contribution statement Shuo Wang: Conceptualization, Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: Insights into the CO oxidation and sulfur tolerance over supported Pt catalysts were carried out. The nominal 1 wt% Pt was loaded onto Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2, and SnO2 by the incipient wetness impregnation method. Results showed that the presence of H2O would promote the catalytic oxidation of CO, and Pt/TiO2 and Pt/SnO2 catalysts showed superior catalytic activity. In combination with a series of characterizations, it was concluded that excellent catalytic activity was dependent on higher dispersion and strong metal support interaction (SMSI) whether water is present or not. In the coexistence of H2O and SO2, the sulfation of the support will lead to the deactivation of the catalyst. Sulfur resistance can be improved over TiO2 with low sulfate decomposition temperature. While for Pt/SnO2 catalyst, its superior sulfur-tolerance was strongly associated with its special core-shell structure. It provides guidelines for the development of catalysts with excellent CO catalytic activity and sulfur tolerance.
coredata.dc:title: CO oxidation with Pt catalysts supported on different supports: A comparison of their sulfur tolerance properties
